channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: DealBook: JPMorgan Chase’s Fruitful Ties to a Member of China’s Elite
item.description: A contract between JPMorgan Chase and a consulting firm run by the daughter of the former prime minister points to the bank’s strategy to build its influence in China.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA, JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and BEN PROTESS

item.title: German Central Bank Warns of Strains From Low Rates
item.description: The Bundesbank said that record low official interest rates in Europe had eroded profits and investments at German banks and insurers.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: India Ink: India Pays Homage as Its Greatest Cricketer Nears Retirement
item.description: Over five days, India will hold its breath as it bids farewell to Sachin Tendulkar, its greatest, and most beloved, sporting hero.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: An artist working on a mural of cricketer Sachin Tendulkar on the wall of a sports club building in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Nov. 8.

item.title: Former German President Goes on Trial
item.description: Christian Wulff resigned in 2012 after prosecutors began investigating allegations that he accepted bribes and favors from businessmen.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Hezbollah Leader Says His Forces Will Remain in Syria
item.description: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the militant group, was addressing tens of thousands of followers marking a major Shiite religious commemoration.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Fine Line for Activists in Russia
item.description: The Arctic protesters are joining such other emblems of Moscow’s iron hand as the Pussy Riot rock band and the former tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: At a United Nations climate convention in Warsaw this week, Greenpeace activists held pictures showing the portraits of people who were arrested in Russia over a protest against Arctic oil drilling.

item.title: Traumatized City in the Philippines Begins to Bury Its Dead
item.description: Unidentified bodies were added to a mass grave outside Tacloban on Thursday, six days after the city was largely destroyed by Typhoon Haiyan.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Increases Aid to Typhoon-Battered Philippines
item.description: The initial donation of $100,000 was widely criticized as inadequate.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philippine soldiers unloading relief supplies at the airport in Tacloban.

item.title: China Increases Aid to Philippines
item.description: After criticism that its initial donation was too small, China will provide $1.4 million in relief supplies, the state news agency said.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Euro Zone Economy Stalls as Germany and France Backtrack
item.description: Output slowed in Germany, Europe’s largest economy, and declined in France, the statistical agency of the European Union reported.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Chinese Rights Campaigner Held Hunger Strike, Lawyer Says
item.description: Yang Maodong was detained by the police in early August on allegations of “assembling a crowd to disrupt order in a public place.”
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Former Political Editor of Open Magazine Hartosh Singh Bal
item.description: Mr. Bal spoke about his unexpected termination from the magazine.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Hartosh Singh Bal, former political editor of Open magazine.

item.title: Overshadowed by Tacloban, Other Devastated Philippine Cities Fear Aid Will Not Come
item.description: In Ormoc, more than 90 percent of the structures are said to have been destroyed or damaged, and food shortages are becoming an increasing problem.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Japan Honors Chinese Student for Heroism
item.description: Yan Jun’s rescue of a Japanese boy from drowning, at risk to his own life, came at a difficult time in relations between China and Japan.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Yan Jun, left, receiving a certificate of commendation from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan for saving a 9-year-old boy.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Northern Chinese Brace for Smog Spike as Winter Heating Kicks In
item.description: On Friday, coal-fired heating systems will be turned on in much of northern China, a major factor in worsening air pollution.
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the chimneys of a heating plant near a residential compound in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Moving to End Some Cosmetics Testing on Animals
item.description: Chinese animal rights advocates are buoyed by news the government is moving toward ending the mandatory testing of cosmetics on animals, in line with growing international norms.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Official Criticized for a Reference to Rape
item.description: During a public debate on gambling, one of India’s top law enforcement officials remarked that arguing to legalize betting is “like saying if you can’t prevent rape, enjoy it.”
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Lawyer Concedes Mistakes in Chevron Case
item.description: In testimony prepared for delivery in court next week, Steven Donziger is as defiant as ever, even as he acknowledges mistakes.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Donziger won a judgment against Chevron.

item.title: Guerrillas Step Up Campaign in Paraguay
item.description: The Paraguayan People’s Army, a shadowy rebel group, is evolving into a broader security threat as it carries out attack after attack on police and army posts.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: From the Shadows, a Rebel Group Vexes Paraguay
item.description: The Paraguayan People’s Army is evolving from a ghostlike irritant for the authorities into a broader security threat.

item.title: Philippines’ President Faces Growing Anger
item.description: Filipinos are losing patience with Benigno S. Aquino III after he apparently was caught off guard by the scope of the calamity wrought by a typhoon.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Filipinos displaced by the typhoon took shelter Wednesday at the Capitol building in Tacloban.

item.title: At a Philippine Hospital, Survivors Face Quiet Despair
item.description: The main hospital in Tacloban, the Philippine city that bore the brunt of Typhoon Haiyan, lacks the supplies to help the wounded, with some just left to die.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Richard Pulga, 27, is in a hospital in Tacloban, but with not even antibiotics to treat him, doctors say his prognosis is grim.

item.title: Council Asks Toronto Mayor to Step Down Temporarily
item.description: A court also released documents documents that painted a salacious picture of a combative, drunken mayor who assaulted staff members and entertained suspected prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Saudi Arabia Officially Rejects U.N. Security Council Seat
item.description: By rejecting the seat it won last month, Saudi Arabia cleared the way for a replacement country to be chosen, diplomatic officials said Wednesday.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Elected to United Nations Human Rights Council
item.description: Saying it would “oppose pressure and confrontation” on the United Nations Human Rights Council and advance the cause of human rights, China was elected to it for a three-year term along with Cuba, Saudi Arabia and Russia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
